articles.headline: In China, the Dangers of Due Diligence
articles.snippet: Background checks, audits and other investigations are just part of doing business in most countries, but in China those jobs can pose big risks.
articles.abstract: Background checks, audits and other investigations are just part of doing business in most countries, but in China those jobs can pose big risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — When Peter Humphrey and his wife, Yu Yingzeng, appeared on Chinese national television recently, handcuffed and wearing orange prison vests, it was the first time in more than a month that family and friends had seen the British-American couple, well-known figures in the foreign business world here.

articles.headline: An Adage Adjustment for Investors at Retirement
articles.snippet: A study found that holding as little as 20 percent in stocks at retirement, and adding more over time, could make a portfolio last longer.
articles.abstract: A study found that holding as little as 20 percent in stocks at retirement, and adding more over time, could make a portfolio last longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s the kind of advice that people approaching retirement long to hear: you may not need to keep as much of your hard-earned savings in stocks.

articles.headline: New Metric for Colleges: Graduates’ Salaries
articles.snippet: PayScale offers an alternative to the U.S News rankings of universities, listing them by the average earnings of their graduates. Not everyone agrees with that approach.
articles.abstract: PayScale offers an alternative to the U.S News rankings of universities, listing them by the average earnings of their graduates. Not everyone agrees with that approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: U.S. News & World Report released its eagerly anticipated annual rankings of universities and colleges this week, and two of the usual suspects — Princeton University and Williams College — came out on top. Prospective students and their parents can evaluate these institutions on a variety of measures deemed important by U.S. News.

articles.headline: U.S.-Russia Talks on Syria’s Arms Make Progress
articles.snippet: American and Russian negotiators meeting in Geneva on Friday moved closer to an agreement that would seek to ultimately strip Syria of its chemical weapons.
articles.abstract: American and Russian negotiators meeting in Geneva on Friday moved closer to an agreement that would seek to ultimately strip Syria of its chemical weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will not insist on a United Nations Security Council resolution threatening Syria with military action, senior administration officials said Friday, as American and Russian negotiators meeting in Geneva moved closer to an agreement that would seek to ultimately strip Syria of its chemical weapons.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: U.S. Coal Companies Scale Back Export Goals
articles.snippet: American mining companies confront a global coal glut and a price slump, along with persistent environmental opposition.
articles.abstract: American mining companies confront a global coal glut and a price slump, along with persistent environmental opposition.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The ailing American coal industry, which has pinned its hopes on exports to counter a declining market at home, is scaling back its ambitions as demand from abroad starts to ebb as well.

articles.headline: California Inland Empire Still in Housing Tailspin
articles.snippet: Five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the Inland Empire, where it financed hundreds of subprime loans, is still a long way from recovery.
articles.abstract: Five years after the collapse of Lehman Brothers, the Inland Empire, where it financed hundreds of subprime loans, is still a long way from recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — The one-story home that Scott and Summer Gieser just moved into is a far cry from the new two-story, four-bedroom house they owned before the great mortgage collapse.

articles.headline: The Payday at Twitter Many Were Waiting For
articles.snippet: Twitter’s public offering will not be nearly as large as Facebook’s $16 billion offering, but it will still create dozens of multimillionaires.
articles.abstract: Twitter’s public offering will not be nearly as large as Facebook’s $16 billion offering, but it will still create dozens of multimillionaires.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In June 2007, Evan Williams was looking for investors for a quirky Internet communications service called Twitter that he had co-founded.
articles.byline: By Nick Bilton and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Girl’s Suicide Points to Rise in Apps Used by Cyberbullies
articles.snippet: Rebecca Ann Sedwick, 12, leaped to her death from a platform at an abandoned cement plant near her home in Florida, in a case that highlights the growing use of cellphone apps for cyberbullying.
articles.abstract: Rebecca Ann Sedwick, 12, leaped to her death from a platform at an abandoned cement plant near her home in Florida, in a case that highlights the growing use of cellphone apps for cyberbullying.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The clues were buried in her bedroom. Before leaving for school on Monday morning, Rebecca Ann Sedwick had hidden her schoolbooks under a pile of clothes and left her cellphone behind, a rare lapse for a 12-year-old girl.

articles.headline: U.S. and Russia Reach Deal to Destroy Syria’s Chemical Arms
articles.snippet: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, set the stage for one of the most challenging undertakings in the history of arms control.
articles.abstract: The announcement by Secretary of State John Kerry and the Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, set the stage for one of the most challenging undertakings in the history of arms control.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United States and Russia reached a sweeping agreement on Saturday that called for Syria’s arsenal of chemical weapons to be removed or destroyed by the middle of 2014 and indefinitely stalled the prospect of American airstrikes.

articles.headline: After a Financial Flood, Pipes Are Still Broken
articles.snippet: Five years after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market — the plumbing of the financial system — is a big liability as it operates on trust.
articles.abstract: Five years after the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy, the $4.6 trillion wholesale funding market — the plumbing of the financial system — is a big liability as it operates on trust.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT’S been five years since the bankruptcy filing of Lehman Brothers set off the worst economic crisis in the United States since the Great Depression. With the perspective that distance provides, it’s worth asking: Is our financial system safer and sounder today than it was back then?

articles.headline: Taste-Testing a Second Career, With a Mentor
articles.snippet: Is that dream job all that it seems? Hire-a-mentor services want to help you decide — whether you want to become a coffeehouse owner, a D.J. or an Episcopal priest.
articles.abstract: Is that dream job all that it seems? Hire-a-mentor services want to help you decide — whether you want to become a coffeehouse owner, a D.J. or an Episcopal priest.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOD, as we know, works in mysterious ways. Back in the spring of 2011, Gerry Owen, an assistant pastor at a megachurch in Garland, Tex., was reading through the comment cards that worshipers drop in a box at the back of the church after Sunday services. He came across a card from a worshiper who also happened to be the owner of Generator Coffee, the coffee shop where Mr. Owen, who is 55, and his second wife, Melissa, had married just several months before.

articles.headline: Proudly Private, a Wall Street Brokerage Firm Marches On
articles.snippet: The investment bank Sandler O’Neill, one of the last major private partnerships on Wall Street, also takes fewer risks than others in the industry.
articles.abstract: The investment bank Sandler O’Neill, one of the last major private partnerships on Wall Street, also takes fewer risks than others in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, most bankers are paid a convoluted formula of cash and stock that’s determined by committee. At the boutique brokerage firm Sandler O’Neill, it’s old school: Everyone gets cash and one opinion matters most: Jimmy Dunne’s.

articles.headline: Biden and Clinton: Friends With Awkward Twist
articles.snippet: The bond of affection and regard between the vice president and the former secretary of state is by all accounts genuine and of long standing, but it has also endured many strains.
articles.abstract: The bond of affection and regard between the vice president and the former secretary of state is by all accounts genuine and of long standing, but it has also endured many strains.
articles.lead_paragraph: In December 2011, pollsters working for President Obama’s re-election campaign asked voters in battleground states a question: Would you be more likely to vote for Mr. Obama if Hillary Rodham Clinton were to campaign for him?

articles.headline: If History Is Any Measure, the Clock Is Ticking
articles.snippet: Weapons experts and diplomats say that if President Bashar al-Assad is serious about giving up his arsenal, he will have to take dramatic action in the coming weeks.
articles.abstract: Weapons experts and diplomats say that if President Bashar al-Assad is serious about giving up his arsenal, he will have to take dramatic action in the coming weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had to convince the world 10 years ago that he was serious about giving up his chemical weapons, he dragged warheads and bombs into the desert and flattened them with bulldozers.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Wall St. Exploits Ethanol Credits, and Prices Spike
articles.snippet: A little known market in ethanol credits arose after financial institutions amassed millions of them — just as refiners were looking to buy more credits to meet an expanding federal requirement.
articles.abstract: A little known market in ethanol credits arose after financial institutions amassed millions of them — just as refiners were looking to buy more credits to meet an expanding federal requirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to help clean the air, reduce dependence on foreign oil and bolster agriculture. But a little known market in ethanol credits has also become a hot new game on Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: At Frankfurt Automobile Show, the Driver Began to Take a Back Seat
articles.snippet: At the Frankfurt motor show last week, there was a palpable sense that technology for autonomous driving was moving quickly from laboratories to dealers.
articles.abstract: At the Frankfurt motor show last week, there was a palpable sense that technology for autonomous driving was moving quickly from laboratories to dealers.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A wide grin beneath his bushy mustache, Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of Daimler, did as car executives often do at auto shows, cruising onto the stage in the company’s newest model. But at the Frankfurt motor show last week, Mr. Zetsche added a surprise: he sprang from the back of a Mercedes S-Class that had no one in the driver’s seat.

articles.headline: Summers Pulls Name From Consideration for Fed Chief
articles.snippet: Facing growing opposition in Congress, Lawrence H. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and a top contender for Federal Reserve chairman, told President Obama that he didn’t want to be considered for the job.
articles.abstract: Facing growing opposition in Congress, Lawrence H. Summers, the former Treasury secretary and a top contender for Federal Reserve chairman, told President Obama that he didn’t want to be considered for the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For Lawrence H. Summers, President Obama’s preferred candidate to lead the Federal Reserve, the messy debate over a military attack in Syria was the final sign.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and Binyamin Appelbaum

articles.headline: New Course for ‘Weekend Update,’ and All of ‘SNL’
articles.snippet: Cecily Strong will become an anchor on the “Saturday Night Live” “Weekend Update” desk, and six performers will join the cast for this next season.
articles.abstract: Cecily Strong will become an anchor on the “Saturday Night Live” “Weekend Update” desk, and six performers will join the cast for this next season.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his cast depleted of some of its most talented and most loved performers of recent vintage, Lorne Michaels had an exceptionally busy summer vacation from “Saturday Night Live,” the show he created and still produces.

articles.headline: Retailers Fight Exile From Gmail In-Boxes
articles.snippet: Google introduced five new folders for its Gmail service over the summer, including one for promotions that puts retailers’ e-mail under a separate heading.
articles.abstract: Google introduced five new folders for its Gmail service over the summer, including one for promotions that puts retailers’ e-mail under a separate heading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even in an age of Twitter posts and Instagram photos, e-mail is still the way marketers reach the hearts — and wallets — of consumers. And that is why retailers are up in arms about Google’s latest tweak to Gmail.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Hollywood Wants Numbers on the Digital Box Office
articles.snippet: As digital distribution takes off, some players in the film business are chafing about a lack of open information on how movies perform in on-demand channels.
articles.abstract: As digital distribution takes off, some players in the film business are chafing about a lack of open information on how movies perform in on-demand channels.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The movie industry is whooshing toward its digital future, but some players are worried about getting stuck in an informational void along the way.

articles.headline: Storytelling Ads May Be Journalism’s New Peril
articles.snippet: Native advertising is advertising that wears the uniform of journalism, mimicking the storytelling aesthetic of the host site. Some say it could dilute the power of a brand over time.
articles.abstract: Native advertising is advertising that wears the uniform of journalism, mimicking the storytelling aesthetic of the host site. Some say it could dilute the power of a brand over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the guy who ruined the Internet with banner ads tells you that a new kind of advertising might destroy journalism, it tends to get your attention.

articles.headline: Politico Plans for New York Are Drawing Some Doubt
articles.snippet: Some wonder if there is room in the city for another political and media Web site, even if it is made in the image of successful Politico.
articles.abstract: Some wonder if there is room in the city for another political and media Web site, even if it is made in the image of successful Politico.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until last week, Capital New York was an obscure Web publication that covered New York City culture and politics with a handful of staff members. It produced long, thoughtful pieces on topics like the Metropolitan Opera and the finances of the New York Mets and had some media and political scoops, but it also struggled to pay freelancers on time and to get the credit the editors thought they deserved.

articles.headline: Looking to Twitter to Reignite Tech I.P.O.’s
articles.snippet: Now investors and deal makers hope that Twitter’s stock sale will help the once-soaring tech sector take flight again.
articles.abstract: Now investors and deal makers hope that Twitter’s stock sale will help the once-soaring tech sector take flight again.
articles.lead_paragraph: Beginning in 2011, the market for technology initial public offerings exploded with a number of blockbuster offerings — but went quiet soon after Facebook’s $16 billion stock sale last year.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles

articles.headline: Deal Represents Turn for Syria; Rebels Deflated
articles.snippet: The accord on chemical arms is seen as a major turning point by both sides in Syria, leaving the rebels deflated and government supporters jubilant.
articles.abstract: The accord on chemical arms is seen as a major turning point by both sides in Syria, leaving the rebels deflated and government supporters jubilant.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Both sides in Syria’s civil war see the deal to dismantle President Bashar al-Assad’s chemical weapons stockpiles as a major turning point. It left rebels deflated and government supporters jubilant. And both sides say it means the United States knows Mr. Assad is not going anywhere anytime soon.

articles.headline: Trading Privilege for Privation, Family Hits a Nerve in South Africa
articles.snippet: A white middle-class family’s decision to move to a poor black township for a month had many debating whether it was about empathy or slum tourism.
articles.abstract: A white middle-class family’s decision to move to a poor black township for a month had many debating whether it was about empathy or slum tourism.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAMELODI, South Africa — Regina Matshega was gossiping with a neighbor over a fence between their shacks in the Phomolong squatter camp last month when a very unexpected sight suddenly popped into view: two ruddy-cheeked white South Africans, a man and a woman, with two towheaded toddlers running at their heels.

articles.headline: Vietnam Legacy: Finding G.I. Fathers, and Children Left Behind
articles.snippet: For veterans longing to salve the scars of an old war and their half-Vietnamese children wanting to know their roots, the need to find one another has become more urgent than ever.
articles.abstract: For veterans longing to salve the scars of an old war and their half-Vietnamese children wanting to know their roots, the need to find one another has become more urgent than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALTILLO, Miss. — Soon after he departed Vietnam in 1970, Specialist James Copeland received a letter from his Vietnamese girlfriend. She was pregnant, she wrote, and he was the father.

articles.headline: Brief Respite for President, but No Plan B on Syria
articles.snippet: The Russian-American deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons gives President Obama some breathing space, but the list of things that could still go wrong is daunting.
articles.abstract: The Russian-American deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons gives President Obama some breathing space, but the list of things that could still go wrong is daunting.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Russian-American deal to destroy Syria’s chemical weapons arsenal gives President Obama some breathing space after a politically damaging few weeks. But the list of things that could still go wrong is extensive and daunting.

articles.headline: Gunman and 12 Victims Killed in Shooting at D.C. Navy Yard
articles.snippet: A former Navy reservist killed at least 12 people on Monday in a mass shooting at a naval office building in Washington, and then was killed by the police, officials said.
articles.abstract: A former Navy reservist killed at least 12 people on Monday in a mass shooting at a naval office building in Washington, and then was killed by the police, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Navy reservist killed at least 12 people on Monday in a mass shooting at a secure military facility that led the authorities to lock down part of the nation’s capital — even after the gunman was killed — in a hunt for two other armed men spotted by video cameras, officials said.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Forensic Details in U.N. Report Point to Assad’s Use of Gas
articles.snippet: The report provided incriminating new evidence of Syrian government culpability in the Aug. 21 attack, in which banned chemical weapons were used.
articles.abstract: The report provided incriminating new evidence of Syrian government culpability in the Aug. 21 attack, in which banned chemical weapons were used.
articles.lead_paragraph: A United Nations report released on Monday confirmed that a deadly chemical arms attack caused a mass killing in Syria last month and for the first time provided extensive forensic details of the weapons used, which strongly implicated the Syrian government.
articles.byline: By Rick Gladstone and C. J. Chivers
